title: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit, Allows Tree Removal
excerpt:
On Friday, July 18, 2025, members of FFGP spoke with Brooklyn News 12 to voice their disappointment in the ruling. "This decision represents a setback not only for Fort Greene Park but for all New Yorkers who believe in protecting our city's green spaces and honoring our shared historical and cultural heritage," said FFGP President Kelly Schaffer.
Despite the court's decision, the group emphasized that their fight is far from over. FFGP vowed to continue mobilizing neighbors, raising awareness, and pressing city officials to adopt the community's counter-proposal — one that preserves the tree canopy, restores historic landscape features, and ensures the park remains accessible, sustainable, and welcoming for future generations.
author: Staff Reporter

title: Advocates Battle NYC Parks Plan to Cut 78 Trees
excerpt: The nonprofit Friends of Fort Greene Park says the NYC Parks Department failed to conduct a full environmental review before approving a $24 million redesign that would remove 78 mature trees. A March court hearing highlighted the group's argument that the Parks Department violated the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA) and withheld information. The plan, rooted in a 2017 "Parks Without Borders" proposal, initially targeted 58 healthy trees for a paved plaza and new entrance and has since grown in cost and scope. FFGP attorneys say tree removal will harm NYCHA residents who rely on shaded mounds for picnics and exercise, and argue that repairs like drainage improvement and ADA ramps could be done without cutting trees.
author: BK Reader Staff

title: Brooklyn Residents Fight Plan to Chop Down 78 Trees
excerpt: The New York Post reports that residents of Fort Greene are fighting NYC Parks' plan to remove 78 healthy trees in the park. Opponents warn that paving over green space will increase heat and create a 'summer frying pan,' arguing that cutting mature shade trees harms community health and the neighborhood's character. Supporters of the redesign claim it will improve accessibility and public safety.
author: Nicole Rosenthal

title: Advocates and City Continue Legal Battle Over Fort Greene Park Revamp
excerpt: A Brooklyn Paper article chronicles the ongoing legal battle between advocates and NYC Parks over the Fort Greene Park revamp. Advocates say the $24 million redesign would cut down 78 trees without adequate environmental review, while the city contends that some trees are unhealthy or invasive and promises to plant native species. The piece notes that residents and organizations have sued to block the redesign and to compel a full environmental impact review.
author: Kirstyn Brendlen

title: Long-Running Controversy Over Fort Greene Tree Plan Continues
excerpt: The Brooklyn Daily Eagle reports that the controversy over a $24 million redesign of Fort Greene Park—which will axe 78 mature trees—continues. The plan would swap invasive Norway maples for 200 native trees, add ADA entrances and improve drainage, according to the park's Conservancy, which says many trees are unhealthy or invasive. Friends of Fort Greene Park argues the redesign skipped environmental reviews, decreases shade, replaces green space with concrete and destroys park features, and notes that lawsuits against the plan date back to 2019.
author: Brooklyn Eagle Staff

title: 'Tree Fight' Continues to Grow in Brooklyn
excerpt: A CBS News New York segment titled "Tree fight" continues to grow in Brooklyn reports that two organizations hoping to make improvements to Fort Greene Park have been arguing for decades and that the fight has moved to the courts. The piece features video interviews with residents and advocates, highlighting the long-running dispute over plans to cut down 78 mature trees and remodel the park for a $24 million redesign.
author: Kristie Keleshian

title: Residents Sue to Stop Tree Cutting in $24M Fort Greene Park Overhaul
excerpt: FOX5 New York reports that a $24 million project to redesign Fort Greene Park faces legal opposition from local residents. The plan calls for the removal of 78 trees to make way for pedestrian plazas and increased accessibility, but opponents say the project will harm the environment and community health. Residents filed a lawsuit arguing that tree loss will impact air quality, wildlife and shade in a neighborhood already affected by asthma and heat.
author: Kendall Green

title: 'Living for the City' Discusses Fort Greene Park Controversy
excerpt: During WBAI Radio's "Living for the City" program on May 14, 2025, hosts discussed Mt. Prospect Park and Fort Greene Park, explaining the issues surrounding NYC Parks' plan to remove 78 mature trees and redesign the park. The segment provided background on the decades-long fight, the lawsuits and the community counter-proposal to preserve trees, restore historic features and improve accessibility without extensive tree removal.
author: WBAI Radio
